comment.author: 32162360@N00
47201412@N02
comment._content: "Sydneyites ... send carriages behind their locomotives as tall as ordinary houses. ... It was some time before we ventured on board one of these moving buildings. ... As we went along we had splendid views into bed-rooms, bath-rooms, store-rooms, top garrets, and generally the upper quarters of the houses which lined a street. Now and then a hand would suddenly snap down a blind." - Mark Kershaw (1886) Colonial Facts and Fictions - Humorous Sketches, pp. 102-4 quoted in Gaslight Sydney by Louise Johnson (Sydney: George Allen & Unwin, 1984), p. 48. For an artwork of this tram on the first night it ran, see here

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: What a wonderful description! How strange it would have been to have 'moving people' peering into your upper level rooms.

comment.author: 72791995@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Australian Bus and Tram photos, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 36196524@N08
comment._content: This tram is notable for its lack of destination signs, which in those days were generally pretty good.  It might have given us a clue as to the location of the photo.
